summary: This is a government reply letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Alison J. Nathan, opposing Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to exclude Government Exhibit 52 (a bound address book). The government argues that Employee-1 can authenticate the exhibit as a copy of Maxwell's address book based on its appearance, contents, corroborating evidence, and the household practice of keeping copies by telephones.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (S2 20 Cr. 330) who moved to exclude Government Exhibit 52, an address book.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case to whom this government reply letter is addressed.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted this reply letter.

persons.name: Employee-1
persons.context: A former employee of Jeffrey Epstein who worked for him in 2005-2006 and is expected to testify to authenticate Government Exhibit 52 as a copy of Maxwell's address book.

connections.description: Employee-1 worked for Jeffrey Epstein and observed Maxwell's address book in Epstein's house, indicating Maxwell was associated with the household.
The address book is referred to as 'Mr Epstein and Ms Maxwell's telephone directories' in the household manual (GX 606), indicating a shared household and association.

events.title: Sentencing of [Redacted Individual]
events.description: Sentencing hearing in a separate case (United States v. [Redacted], 10 Cr. 80015) where counsel stated the individual possessed 'a copy of the book, of which there were many copies' from Epstein's house.

events.title: [Redacted Individual]'s Employment with Epstein
events.description: A redacted individual (referred to in the plea agreement) worked for Jeffrey Epstein during 2004 and 2005 and later possessed a copy of the address book.

events.title: Employee-1's Employment with Epstein
events.description: Employee-1 worked for Jeffrey Epstein during 2005 and 2006, overlapping with the period the address book was in use in the household.

keyFacts: Government Exhibit 52 is a bound, sewn, typed address book with a distinctive cover that the government claims is a copy of Ghislaine Maxwell's address book.
Employee-1 will testify that multiple identical copies of this address book were kept in specific places in Epstein's Palm Beach house, a practice corroborated by a household manual (GX 606).

A redacted individual ([Redacted]) possessed a copy of the same address book after leaving Epstein's employment, and was sentenced to 18 months in prison for concealing it during a grand jury investigation.

The government argues the low bar for authentication is met because Employee-1 can recognize the exhibit as one of the many copies she saw, and its contents contain private information of people who knew Maxwell.

The defense's forgery theory is challenged by the government, noting the book is sewn and bound, making alteration difficult, and any minor additions (like sticky notes) go to weight, not admissibility.
